spirit:abstractionDefinition.spirit:name: CHI-C-RNF_rtl

spirit:port.spirit:description: Synchronous clock for this interface

Clock enable signal. Used as a qualifier for the CLK signal. This signal indicates which rising edges of CLK should be acted upon: 1 = valid rising edge of ACLK, 0 = any rising edge of ACLK should be ignored and no bus-state altered.
Asynchronous assert, synchronous deasserted reset signal
TX Link Activation Request Signal.
TX Link Activation Acknowledgement Signal.
RX Link Activation Request Signal.
RX Link Activation Acknowledgement Signal.
Protocol activity indicator. TXSACTIVE signal indicates that the protocol layer of the RNF is active - i.e., there are active transactions either initiated by the node or by the interconnect.

Protocol activity indicator. RXSACTIVE signal indicates that the protocol layer of the interconnect is active - i.e., there are active transactions either initiated by the node or by the interconnect.
FLITPEND signal for TXREQ VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for TXREQ VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Target Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component to which the message is targeted. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port to which the message is routed.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.
Identifies the node SN-F needs to send CompData response to. It can be either the NID of the Home or NID of the Transaction Requester.

This field is applicable in Stash requests only and is defined as below: 1'b1: The StashNID field in the Request has a valid Stash target. 1'b0: StashNID field value is a do not care and must be set to zero. The field is inapplicable in all other requests.

The field is applicable only in ReadNoSnp from HN-F to SN-F. Identifies the value SN-F must use in TxnID field of the CompData response. It can be either the TxnID generated by Home for this transaction or the TxnID in Request packet from the Transaction requester. The field is inapplicable in all other requests. ReturnTxnID when inapplicable must be set to zero.
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.
Size. Specifies the size of the data associated with the transaction.
Specifies the address associated with the message: - Request messages support a 44-52 bit address field, Addr[43:0].
Indicates a Non-secure access or a Secure access. [0 - Secure access, 1 - Non-secure access]
Likely Shared. Indicates whether the requested data is likely to be shared with another RN. [0 - Not likely to be shared by another RN, 1 - Likely to be shared by another RN]

Allow Retry. Specifies that the request is being sent without a P-Credit and that the target can determine if a retry response is given. [0 - RetryAck response not permitted, 1 - RetryAck response permitted]

Specifies the ordering requirements for a transaction. [0b00 - No ordering required, 0b01 - Reserved, 0b10 - Request Order/Ordered Write Observation, 0b11 - Endpoint Order, which also includes Request Order]
Protocol Credit Type. Indicates the type of credit being granted or returned.
Memory attribute associated with the transaction.
Memory attribute associated with the transaction. [0b00 - Non-snoopable, 0b01 - Snoopable]
Logical Processor Identifier. Used in conjunction with the SrcID to uniquely identify the logical processor that generated the request.

Exclusive bit. Indicates that the corresponding transaction is an Exclusive type transaction. [0 - Normal transaction, 1 - Exclusive transaction] The Exclusive bit must only be used with the following transactions: - ReadShared - ReadClean - CleanUnique - ReadNoSnp - WriteNoSnp
Expect CompAck bit. Indicates that the transaction will include a CompAck response. [0 - Transaction does not include a CompAck response, 1 - Transaction includes a CompAck response]
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Reserved for customer use. Any value is valid in a Protocol flit. Propagation of this field through the interconnect is IMPLEMENTATION DEFINED.
Link layer credit signal for TXREQ VC. A TXREQ flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
FLITPEND signal for TXRSP VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for TXRSP VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Target Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component to which the message is targeted. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port to which the message is routed.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.

This field indicates the error status of the response. [0b00 - Normal Okay. Indicates that either: The Normal access was successful. The Exclusive access failed, 0b01 - Exclusive Okay. Indicates that either the read or write portion of an exclusive access was successful. 0b10 - Data Error. 0b11 - Non-data Error.]
Response Status. The Resp field must have the same value in all data flits of a multi-flit data transfer.

Applicable in SnpRespFwded response only. FwdState[2] PassDirty. Indicates that the data included in the response message sent to Requester is Dirty with respect to memory and that the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed to the Requester. 1'b0 : Forwarded data is not Dirty. 1'b1 : Forwarded data is Dirty and the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed on. FwdState[1:0] Indicates the final state in the Requester.
Data Buffer Identifier. The DBID is associated with a Write transaction. In response to Write requests, the DBID is sent to the requester.
Protocol Credit Type. Indicates the type of credit being granted or returned.
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Link layer credit signal for TXRSP VC. A TXRSP flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
FLITPEND signal for TXDAT VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for TXDAT VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Target Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component to which the message is targeted. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port to which the message is routed.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.
7-11-bit node ID of the component ...
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.

This field indicates the error status of the response. [0b00 - Normal Okay. Indicates that either: The Normal access was successful. The Exclusive access failed, 0b01 - Exclusive Okay. Indicates that either the read or write portion of an exclusive access was successful. 0b10 - Data Error. 0b11 - Non-data Error.]
Response Status. The Resp field must have the same value in all data flits of a multi-flit data transfer.

Applicable in SnpRespFwded response only. FwdState[2] PassDirty. Indicates that the data included in the response message sent to Requester is Dirty with respect to memory and that the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed to the Requester. 1'b0 : Forwarded data is not Dirty. 1'b1 : Forwarded data is Dirty and the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed on. FwdState[1:0] Indicates the final state in the Requester.
Data Buffer Identifier. The DBID is associated with a Write transaction. In response to Write requests, the DBID is sent to the requester.
Critical Chunk Identifier. The CCID indicates the critical 128-bit chunk of the data that is being requested. [0b00 - Data[127:0], 0b01 - Data[255:128], 0b10 - Data[383:256], 0b11 - Data[511:384]]
Data Identifier. The DataID indicates the relative position of the data chunk within the 512-bit cache line that is being transferred.
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Reserved for customer use. Any value is valid in a Protocol flit. Propagation of this field through the interconnect is IMPLEMENTATION DEFINED.

Byte Enable. The BE field is defined for write data, DVM payload, and snoop response data transfers. For read response data transfers, this field can have any value. It consists of a bit for each data byte in the DAT flit.
Data payload. The following data bus widths are supported: 128-bit, 256-bit, 512-bit.
Optional field of width 0 or Data width/8.
When Poison (0-8-bit) is supported, DAT packet carries one poison bit per 64 bits of data. Data when marked poison indicates that data must not be consumed by any Requester.
Link layer credit signal for TXDAT VC. A TXDAT flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
FLITPEND signal for RXRSP VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for RXRSP VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Target Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component to which the message is targeted. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port to which the message is routed.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.

This field indicates the error status of the response. [0b00 - Normal Okay. Indicates that either: The Normal access was successful. The Exclusive access failed, 0b01 - Exclusive Okay. Indicates that either the read or write portion of an exclusive access was successful. 0b10 - Data Error. 0b11 - Non-data Error.]
Response Status. The Resp field must have the same value in all data flits of a multi-flit data transfer.

Applicable in SnpRespFwded response only. FwdState[2] PassDirty. Indicates that the data included in the response message sent to Requester is Dirty with respect to memory and that the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed to the Requester. 1'b0 : Forwarded data is not Dirty. 1'b1 : Forwarded data is Dirty and the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed on. FwdState[1:0] Indicates the final state in the Requester.
Data Buffer Identifier. The DBID is associated with a Write transaction. In response to Write requests, the DBID is sent to the requester.
Protocol Credit Type. Indicates the type of credit being granted or returned.
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Link layer credit signal for RXRSP VC. A RXRSP flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
FLITPEND signal for RXDAT VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for RXDAT VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Target Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component to which the message is targeted. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port to which the message is routed.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.
7-11-bit node ID of the component ...
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.

This field indicates the error status of the response. [0b00 - Normal Okay. Indicates that either: The Normal access was successful. The Exclusive access failed, 0b01 - Exclusive Okay. Indicates that either the read or write portion of an exclusive access was successful. 0b10 - Data Error. 0b11 - Non-data Error.]
Response Status. The Resp field must have the same value in all data flits of a multi-flit data transfer.

Applicable in SnpRespFwded response only. FwdState[2] PassDirty. Indicates that the data included in the response message sent to Requester is Dirty with respect to memory and that the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed to the Requester. 1'b0 : Forwarded data is not Dirty. 1'b1 : Forwarded data is Dirty and the responsibility of writing back the cache line is being passed on. FwdState[1:0] Indicates the final state in the Requester.
Data Buffer Identifier. The DBID is associated with a Write transaction. In response to Write requests, the DBID is sent to the requester.
Critical Chunk Identifier. The CCID indicates the critical 128-bit chunk of the data that is being requested. [0b00 - Data[127:0], 0b01 - Data[255:128], 0b10 - Data[383:256], 0b11 - Data[511:384]]
Data Identifier. The DataID indicates the relative position of the data chunk within the 512-bit cache line that is being transferred.
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Reserved for customer use. Any value is valid in a Protocol flit. Propagation of this field through the interconnect is IMPLEMENTATION DEFINED.

Byte Enable. The BE field is defined for write data, DVM payload, and snoop response data transfers. For read response data transfers, this field can have any value. It consists of a bit for each data byte in the DAT flit.
Data payload. The following data bus widths are supported: 128-bit, 256-bit, 512-bit.
Optional field of width 0 or Data width/8.
When Poison (0-8-bit) is supported, DAT packet carries one poison bit per 64 bits of data. Data when marked poison indicates that data must not be consumed by any Requester.
Link layer credit signal for RXDAT VC. A RXDAT flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
FLITPEND signal for RXSNP VC. FLITPEND is an early indication that a flit may be transmitted in the following cycle. It is intended to be used for low-level clock and/or power optimizations.
Flit valid signal for RXSNP VC. FLITV is the indication of a valid flit transfer.
Quality of Service priority level. Ascending values of QoS indicate higher priority levels.

Source Identifier associated with the message. The unique 7-11-bit physical node ID of the component from which the message is sent. This is used by the interconnect to determine the port from which the message has been routed.
Transaction Identifier associated with the message. Every new transaction from a given source node, except a link flit, has a unique 8-bit transaction ID.

The field is applicable only in Forward type Snoops. Identifies the requester to which CompData response can be forwarded. It must be the NID of the Transaction requester. The field is inapplicable in all other snoop requests.

The field is applicable only in Forward type Snoops. Identifies the value to be used in the TxnID of CompData response forwarded to the Transition requester. It must be the TxnID value in the request from the Transaction requester. The field is inapplicable in all other snoop requests
Specifies the operation to be carried out. The Opcode encodings are specific to each channel.
Specifies the address associated with the message: - Snoop messages support a 41-49-bit address field.
Indicates a Non-secure access or a Secure access. [0 - Secure access, 1 - Non-secure access]

The value of the bit is interpreted in the following manner. 1'b1: Transitioning to SD state is not permitted. Leaving the line in SD is not permitted except in the case of SnpOnce, SnpOnceFwd and SnpStashShared. Data is still permitted to be returned to Home in SD state. 1'b0: Permitted to transition to SD state.
Set only with SnpShared, SnpClean, SnpOnce, SnpUnique and SnpNotSharedDirty. Applicable to both Fwd and non-Fwd Snoop types.
TraceTag, a one bit field.
Link layer credit signal for RXSNP VC. A RXSNP flit may only be sent if a corresponding L-credit is available at the transmitter.
Coherency connect request.
Coherency connect acknowledge.

spirit:abstractionDefinition.spirit:description: RTL pin definition for CHI-RNF_rtl interface
